Description: Move await into branches where actually used to avoid blocking unused code paths
Do: Move await operations into branches where they're needed
Don't: Await at top of function blocking all branches
Code Example Good: if (skip) return { skipped: true }; const data = await fetch()
Code Example Bad: const data = await fetch(); if (skip) return { skipped: true }

Description: Execute independent async operations concurrently using Promise.all()
Do: Use Promise.all() for independent operations
Don't: Sequential await for independent operations
Code Example Bad: const user = await fetchUser(); const posts = await fetchPosts()

Description: Start dependent operations as early as possible; use Promise.all with dependency chains
Do: Start each task at earliest possible moment; chain only true dependencies
Don't: Wait for unrelated data before starting dependent fetch
Code Example Good: const userP = fetchUser(); const configP = fetchConfig(); const user = await userP; const profile = await fetchProfile(user.id)
Code Example Bad: const user = await fetchUser(); const config = await fetchConfig(); const profile = await fetchProfile(user.id)

Description: In API routes start independent operations immediately even if not awaited yet
Do: Start promises early and await late
Don't: Sequential awaits in API handlers
Code Example Good: const sessionP = auth(); const configP = fetchConfig(); const session = await sessionP
Code Example Bad: const session = await auth(); const config = await fetchConfig()

Description: Use Suspense to show wrapper UI faster while data loads; enables streaming SSR
Do: Wrap async components in Suspense boundaries with meaningful fallbacks
Don't: Await data blocking entire page render
Code Example Bad: const data = await fetchData(); return <DataDisplay data={data} />

Description: Use the use() hook to read promises in render; integrates with Suspense automatically
Do: Use use(promise) to unwrap async data in components
Don't: Manual promise handling with useEffect + useState

Description: Import directly from source files instead of barrel files to avoid loading unused modules
Do: Import directly from source path; use optimizePackageImports in next.config
Don't: Import from barrel/index files

Description: Use next/dynamic or React.lazy to lazy-load large components not needed on initial render
Do: Use dynamic() for heavy components; set ssr: false for client-only
Don't: Import heavy components at top level
Code Example Good: const Monaco = dynamic(() => import('./monaco'), { ssr: false })

Description: Load analytics and logging after hydration since they don't block interaction
Do: Load non-critical scripts after hydration; use next/script strategy
Don't: Include analytics in main bundle

Description: Load large data or modules only when a feature is activated
Do: Dynamic import when feature enabled; use import() in event handlers
Don't: Import large modules unconditionally

Description: Preload heavy bundles on hover/focus before they're needed for instant interaction
Do: Preload on user intent signals (hover, focus, viewport entry)
Don't: Load only on click causing delay

Description: React Compiler (React Forget) automatically memoizes components and hooks; remove manual memo/useMemo/useCallback
Do: Enable React Compiler; remove manual memoization it handles
Don't: Manually wrap everything in memo/useMemo/useCallback
Code Example Good: // react-compiler enabled in babel config; write plain components
Code Example Bad: const MemoComp = memo(({ data }) => ...); const cb = useCallback(() => {}, [deps])

Description: Use React.cache() for server-side request deduplication within single render pass
Do: Wrap data fetchers with cache() for same-request dedup
Don't: Fetch same data multiple times in component tree
Code Example Good: export const getUser = cache(async () => await db.user.find())
Code Example Bad: export async function getUser() { return await db.user.find() }

Description: Use LRU cache or unstable_cache for data shared across sequential requests
Do: Use LRU or unstable_cache with TTL for cross-request caching
Don't: Refetch same data on every request
Code Example Good: const cache = new LRUCache({ max: 1000, ttl: 5*60*1000 })
Code Example Bad: Always fetch from database on every request

Description: Only pass fields that client actually uses across RSC boundaries; avoid serializing large objects
Do: Pass only needed fields to client components; use pick/select
Don't: Pass entire objects to client components

Description: Restructure components to parallelize data fetching in React Server Components
Do: Use component composition for parallel fetches; sibling async components
Don't: Sequential fetches in parent component
Code Example Good: <Header /><Sidebar /> // both fetch in parallel as siblings

Description: Use Next.js after() to schedule work after response is sent to client
Do: Use after() for logging, analytics, cache warming
Don't: Block response for non-critical operations

Description: Use Server Actions for form mutations; they integrate with Suspense, transitions, and error boundaries
Do: Use 'use server' for mutations; combine with useActionState
Don't: Manual API routes for simple form submissions
Code Example Good: async function submitForm(formData) { 'use server'; await db.insert(formData) }
Code Example Bad: const handleSubmit = async () => { await fetch('/api/submit', { method: 'POST' }) }

Description: Use Partial Prerendering (PPR) to combine static shell with dynamic streaming content
Do: Enable PPR for pages with static + dynamic content; use Suspense boundaries
Don't: Full SSR or full static for mixed pages
Code Example Good: export const experimental_ppr = true; // static shell + Suspense for dynamic
Code Example Bad: // Entire page is either fully static or fully dynamic

Description: Use SWR or TanStack Query for automatic request deduplication and caching
Do: Use useSWR/useQuery for client data fetching with built-in dedup
Don't: Manual fetch in useEffect with no caching

Description: Share global event listeners across component instances to avoid duplicate registrations
Do: Use shared subscription pattern or useSyncExternalStore
Don't: Register listener per component instance

Description: Use useOptimistic for instant UI feedback while server action processes
Do: Use useOptimistic for form submissions and mutations
Don't: Wait for server response before updating UI
Code Example Bad: const handleAdd = async () => { await addItem(); refetch() } // slow feedback

Description: Use useFormStatus to show loading states in form submit buttons
Do: Use useFormStatus inside form children for pending state
Don't: Manual loading state management with useState
Code Example Good: function SubmitButton() { const { pending } = useFormStatus(); return <button disabled={pending}>Submit</button> }
Code Example Bad: const [loading, setLoading] = useState(false); onClick={() => { setLoading(true); await submit(); setLoading(false) }}

Description: Use useActionState for form state management with Server Actions
Do: Use useActionState for form error/success state from server actions
Don't: Manual error state management
Code Example Bad: const [error, setError] = useState(); try { await action() } catch(e) { setError(e) }

Description: Don't subscribe to state only used in callbacks; read on-demand instead
Do: Read state on-demand in callbacks; avoid unnecessary subscriptions
Don't: Subscribe to state used only in handlers
Code Example Good: const handleClick = () => { const params = new URLSearchParams(location.search) }
Code Example Bad: const params = useSearchParams(); const handleClick = () => { params.get('ref') }

Description: React Compiler auto-memoizes; remove manual memo(), useMemo(), useCallback() when compiler is enabled
Do: Enable React Compiler and write plain components
Don't: Manually memoize everything when compiler handles it

Description: Specify primitive dependencies instead of objects in effects to prevent unnecessary re-runs
Do: Use primitive values in dependency arrays
Don't: Use object references as dependencies

Description: Subscribe to derived booleans instead of continuous values to reduce re-renders
Do: Use derived boolean state; useSyncExternalStore for external state
Don't: Subscribe to continuous values causing frequent re-renders
Code Example Bad: const width = useWindowWidth(); const isMobile = width < 768

Description: Use functional setState updates for stable callbacks and no stale closures
Do: Use functional form: setState(curr => ...)
Don't: Reference state directly in setState causing stale closures

Description: Pass function to useState for expensive initial values to avoid recomputation
Do: Use function form for expensive init
Don't: Compute expensive value directly on every render

Description: Mark frequent non-urgent state updates as transitions to keep UI responsive
Do: Use startTransition for non-urgent updates; useTransition for pending state
Don't: Block UI on every state change

Description: Wrap SVG in div and animate wrapper for hardware acceleration
Do: Animate div wrapper around SVG; use will-change: transform
Don't: Animate SVG element directly causing layout thrashing

Description: Apply content-visibility: auto to defer off-screen rendering for long lists
Do: Use content-visibility for long lists; set contain-intrinsic-size
Don't: Render all list items immediately without virtualization

Description: Extract static JSX outside components to avoid re-creation on every render
Do: Hoist static elements to module scope
Don't: Create static elements inside components every render
Code Example Good: const skeleton = <div className='animate-pulse' />; function C() { return skeleton }

Description: Use inline script to set client-only data before hydration to prevent flash
Do: Inject sync script for client-only values (theme, locale)
Don't: Use useEffect causing visible flash of wrong content

Description: Use ternary instead of && when condition can be 0 or NaN to prevent rendering falsy values
Do: Use explicit ternary for conditionals
Don't: Use && with potentially falsy numbers

Description: Use View Transitions API for smooth page transitions and element morphing
Do: Use document.startViewTransition() or Next.js built-in support
Don't: Hard page transitions with no animation

Description: Use Activity component to preserve state/DOM for toggled components without unmounting
Do: Use Activity for expensive toggle components
Don't: Unmount/remount on visibility toggle losing state

Description: Group CSS changes via classes or cssText to minimize reflows
Do: Use class toggle or cssText for batch style changes
Don't: Change styles one property at a time causing multiple reflows

Description: Build Map for repeated lookups instead of multiple .find() calls for O(1) access
Do: Build index Map for O(1) lookups
Don't: Use .find() in loops causing O(nÂ²) complexity
Code Example Good: const byId = new Map(users.map(u => [u.id, u])); byId.get(id)
Code Example Bad: users.find(u => u.id === order.userId) // O(n) each time

Description: Use module-level Map to cache repeated function results
Do: Use Map cache for repeated calls with same inputs
Don't: Recompute same values repeatedly
Code Example Good: const cache = new Map(); if (cache.has(x)) return cache.get(x)

Description: Combine multiple filter/map into single loop for better performance
Do: Single loop for multiple categorizations
Don't: Chain multiple filter() calls iterating array multiple times
Code Example Good: for (const u of users) { if (u.isAdmin) admins.push(u); if (u.isTester) testers.push(u) }

Description: Use Set/Map for O(1) lookups instead of array.includes() for repeated checks
Do: Convert to Set for membership checks
Don't: Use .includes() for repeated checks on large arrays

Description: Use toSorted()/toReversed()/toSpliced() instead of mutating array methods
Do: Use immutable array methods (toSorted, toReversed, toSpliced, with)
Don't: Mutate arrays with sort()/splice()/reverse()

Description: Return early when result is determined to skip unnecessary processing
Do: Return immediately on first error or known result
Don't: Process all items then check errors at the end
Code Example Good: for (const u of users) { if (!u.email) return { error: 'Email required' } }
Code Example Bad: let hasError; for (...) { if (!email) hasError=true }; if (hasError)...

Description: Offload heavy computation (sorting, filtering, parsing) to Web Workers to keep main thread free
Do: Use Web Workers for CPU-intensive tasks; use Comlink for ergonomic API
Don't: Run heavy computation on main thread blocking UI
Code Example Bad: const sorted = largeArray.sort((a,b) => complexCompare(a,b)) // blocks main thread

Description: Use useEffectEvent (or ref pattern) for stable effect subscriptions without re-subscribing
Do: Use useEffectEvent for stable handlers in effects
Don't: Re-subscribe on every callback change

Description: Access latest values in callbacks without adding to dependency arrays
Do: Use useLatest for fresh values in stable callbacks
Don't: Add callback to effect dependencies causing re-runs
Code Example Good: const cbRef = useLatest(cb); useEffect(() => { setTimeout(() => cbRef.current()) }, [])

Description: Use ReadableStream and SSE for AI streaming responses; render tokens incrementally
Do: Use ReadableStream + TextDecoder for token-by-token rendering
Don't: Wait for complete AI response before displaying
Code Example Good: const reader = response.body.getReader(); while (true) { const { done, value } = await reader.read(); appendToken(decode(value)) }
Code Example Bad: const result = await response.json(); setContent(result.text) // waits for full response

Description: Wrap AI response components in Suspense with skeleton fallbacks for streaming
Do: Use Suspense boundaries around AI-generated content sections
Don't: Show blank screen while AI generates response
Code Example Bad:
const response = await generateAI(query); return
{response}
// blocks entire page

Description: Use singleton WebSocket connections with reconnection logic for real-time AI features
Do: Use shared WebSocket instance; implement exponential backoff reconnection
Don't: Create new WebSocket per component mount
Code Example Bad: useEffect(() => { const ws = new WebSocket(url); return () => ws.close() }, []) // per component

Description: Use AbortController to cancel in-flight AI requests when user navigates away or submits new query
Do: Abort previous AI request on new submission; cleanup on unmount
Don't: Let abandoned AI requests complete wasting resources
Code Example Good: const controller = new AbortController(); fetch(url, { signal: controller.signal }); return () => controller.abort()
Code Example Bad: // No cleanup; previous AI request continues running in background

Description: Render AI tokens incrementally without causing full re-renders; use refs for append-only content
Do: Use ref-based DOM manipulation for streaming text; batch state updates
Don't: setState on every token causing thousands of re-renders
Code Example Good: const contentRef = useRef(); reader.onToken = (token) => { contentRef.current.textContent += token }
Code Example Bad: const [text, setText] = useState(''); onToken = (t) => setText(prev => prev + t) // re-render per token

Description: Use next/image for automatic image optimization, lazy loading, and responsive srcset
Do: Use <Image> component with proper width/height/sizes
Don't: Use raw tags without optimization

Description: Lazy-load video content using Intersection Observer; don't autoplay off-screen videos
Do: Load video only when entering viewport; use poster image
Don't: Autoplay all videos on page load consuming bandwidth

Description: Use font-display: swap and preload critical fonts to prevent layout shift and FOIT
Do: Preload critical fonts; use font-display: swap; subset fonts
Don't: Load all font weights/styles blocking render
Code Example Good: <link rel="preload" href="/font.woff2" as="font" crossOrigin />; font-display: swap
Code Example Bad: @font-face { src: url('/font.woff2'); } // no display strategy; blocks render

Description: Forms should work without JavaScript using native form actions; enhance with JS
Do: Use form action attribute; enhance with useActionState
Don't: Forms completely broken without JavaScript

Description: Debounce search inputs and use transitions for non-urgent filter updates
Do: Use useDeferredValue or debounce + startTransition for search
Don't: Fetch on every keystroke without debouncing

Description: Sanitize AI-generated HTML/markdown before rendering to prevent XSS attacks
Do: Use DOMPurify or sanitize-html for AI output; render markdown safely
Don't: Render AI output with dangerouslySetInnerHTML without sanitization

Description: Always validate and sanitize Server Action inputs; never trust client data
Do: Use Zod/Valibot to validate all Server Action inputs
Don't: Trust client-submitted form data without validation
Code Example Good: async function action(formData) { 'use server'; const data = schema.parse(Object.fromEntries(formData)) }
Code Example Bad: async function action(formData) { 'use server'; await db.insert(Object.fromEntries(formData)) } // no validation

Description: Respect prefers-reduced-motion media query; provide static alternatives for all animations
Do: Check prefers-reduced-motion; disable/simplify animations
Don't: Force animations on all users regardless of preference
Code Example Good: const prefersReduced = useMediaQuery('(prefers-reduced-motion: reduce)'); // skip animations
Code Example Bad: <motion.div animate={{ x: 100 }} /> // always animates regardless of user preference

Description: Manage focus on route changes, modal opens, and dynamic content updates
Do: Trap focus in modals; restore focus on close; announce route changes
Don't: Ignore focus management causing keyboard users to lose context

Description: Implement stale-while-revalidate pattern for instant UI with background refresh
Do: Show cached data immediately; revalidate in background
Don't: Show loading spinner while refetching cached data
Code Example Good: const { data } = useSWR(key, fetcher, { revalidateOnFocus: true })
Code Example Bad: const [data, setData] = useState(); useEffect(() => { setLoading(true); fetch().then(setData) }, [])

Description: Use Next.js route segment caching with proper revalidation strategies
Do: Set revalidate per route segment; use tags for targeted invalidation
Don't: No caching strategy; every request hits origin
Code Example Good: export const revalidate = 3600; // or use revalidateTag('products')
Code Example Bad: // No caching; every page request fetches fresh data

Description: Use Error Boundaries with recovery actions; provide meaningful fallback UI
Do: Wrap sections in ErrorBoundary with retry/reset actions
Don't: Let errors crash entire application
Code Example Bad: // No error boundary; unhandled error crashes entire page

Description: Implement graceful degradation for AI failures; show cached/fallback content when AI is unavailable
Do: Retry with exponential backoff; show cached response on failure; degrade gracefully
Don't: Show generic error message when AI fails; no retry logic
Code Example Good: try { return await aiGenerate(prompt) } catch { return cachedResponse ?? fallbackContent }
Code Example Bad: try { return await aiGenerate(prompt) } catch { throw new Error('AI failed') }

Keywords: web vitals lcp cls inp monitoring
Description: Monitor Core Web Vitals (LCP, CLS, INP) in production; set performance budgets
Do: Use web-vitals library or Vercel Analytics; set alerts for regressions
Don't: Deploy without performance monitoring
Code Example Good: import { onLCP, onCLS, onINP } from 'web-vitals'; onLCP(sendToAnalytics)
Code Example Bad: // No performance monitoring; issues discovered by users

Description: Use React DevTools Profiler to identify unnecessary re-renders and slow components
Do: Profile in development; identify components rendering > 16ms
Don't: Guess at performance issues without profiling
Code Example Good: <Profiler id="Feed" onRender={(id, phase, duration) => { if (duration > 16) log(id) }}>
Code Example Bad: // No profiling; optimize based on assumptions
